The compiler team survey (https://hackmd.io/E0i2Re5vQy6iUSPhdo2IiA?view#Summary) includes this note, and I thinks it's important.
With alexcrichton, michaelwoerister, Zoxc and Centril all stopping reviewing in a short period of time the number people who do regular reviews of compiler PRs became smaller, so it became even more important.

Can we encourage something like Google reviewing guide https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/reviewer/?
https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/reviewer/speed.html in particular.

The main thing is "prioritize reviewing over your own individual work" basically.
Reviews unblock further work for multiple people rather than just you, unless you are doing something really infrastructural, so prioritizing it increases our throughput as a team.
The last year I tried to schedule some reviewing time, even it's small, every day and can confirm that it does work like this from my experience.

Realistically, the time until review can be 1-2 days for small PRs and 1 week for large PRs, if we need specific goals.
I could write a bit about how I organize this process, but one point is that allocating only 10 minutes a day to triage the review queue, set status labels, r+ trivial PRs, and respond to trivial questions/CI failures already makes things move better.

One unpleasant aspect of this story is that some people became known as slow reviewers and PRs assigned to them are reassigned, because without reassigning you are never going to do anything productively if it requires multiple PRs.
The PRs are reassigned to more known to be active reviewers, so the reviewing load become skewed.
Yeah, I've been thinking a lot about this lately.
I try to assign time for reviewing every day
but it is challenging, particularly when you add in keeping up with notifications
I wonder if one thing we could do is to kind of gamify a bit -- i.e., celebrating reviewers more, and also that would help to track how the load is both being distributed but also being satisfied
we had some graphs for a time viewing PR latency and the like
I don't doubt that I'm someone known as a "slow reviewer", at best

@Vadim Petrochenkov 's note is indeed important: The idea that a PR awaiting review is indeed higher priority than almost anything a reviewer is likely to have on their plate is an important idea, and one that I don't think I've heard stated quite that way before.
Pointing out what is hopefully obvious, but reviewing isn't as fun as writing code.
Writing docs is also not as fun as writing code for most people :) That's why it might make sense to have more people paid to do this sort of work...
(fwiw, I am one of those oddball people who enjoy writing docs)
I currently feel somewhat review bound, so if there is a good way for a non "contributor" to help out here I would gladly do so.

Sometimes I've thought about picking up a review and leaving feedback but if I don't feel comfortable r+ing then I feel like I'm not really helping because someone else still has to review and now it looks like I'm going to r+ it since I left a review.
I'm not sure what the review etiquette is

Wesley Wiser said:

Sometimes I've thought about picking up a review and leaving feedback but if I don't feel comfortable r+ing then I feel like I'm not really helping because someone else still has to review and now it looks like I'm going to r+ it since I left a review.

I've brought this up before, because I was in the same situation. I just remember that everyone was in favour of having review work being taken away from them. It hasn't always worked out perfectly in practice, but never with an issue that couldn't be remedied by an r- or a follow up
Thanks, that's good to know.

I’m open to something like this.

(currently my reviews are slower than usual and I’ve been reassigning more because I’ve not got much time with exams - they end in four days though - so apologies to anyone who’s felt the effects of that)
I strongly favor people leaving reviews without a final r+
it's very helpful to me to know somebody else already looked it over
so I have to be a bit less picky
it's particularly useful if they call attention to things they're not sure about
or sort of leave comments on the "key areas" of the PR
plus I feel like 99% of my reviews the first round is just me saying "document this, document that"

Along these lines I've thought about what if there was a way for you as a member to communicate your bandwidth to triagebot/highfive, by for example giving a limit on how many S-waiting-on-review PRs can be assigned to you. Then once the all members of a team's queues fill up there's a new status like S-waiting-on-reviewer that's essentially the team wide backlog.

@Jake Goulding I'm the kind of oddball that enjoys doing review work :3
I find the discussion and the back and forth on the PR's topic really satisfying. Also I get to give kudos, which is something I tend to enjoy as well. There are many good practices that go unnoticed, and when I do notice them I like to give some :heart:️s to the coder that followed them :smile:️
I think that @XAMPPRocky's idea could help a lot. Saying beforehand what is exactly your bandwidth is a way of establishing some healthy boundaries, which is never bad
It also ensures that you will tend to have time to review the PRs assigned to you, on a timely manner.

nikomatsakis said:

it's very helpful to me to know somebody else already looked it over

Maybe we should add a tag to PRs that haven't gotten a review in a week that contributors can look for to get into reviewing without any pressure for completeness or anything. Basically how E-mentor is "you implement something, but someone else is in charge of the big picture" for issues, but for reviewing. You review, but you know that your review only helps move things forward and does not put any responsibility on you.

Maybe we should add a tag to PRs that haven't gotten a review in a week

t-release/wg-triage is actually producing reminders on these regularly (several times a week,) the list is currently produced and posted on Discord wg-triage channel. It includes PRs for all teams (also including t-libs and t-rustdoc and so on) though.

Also I get to give kudos, which is something I tend to enjoy as well. There are many good practices that go unnoticed, and when I do notice them I like to give some :heart:️s to the coder that followed them :smile:️

This is one of the most powerful things you can do during a review, @Félix Fischer and it’s something that I’m terrible at. It’s heartening to know that other people actually do it.

I know I've sometimes been slow to review stuff. That's mostly because when I use my free time in the evening/weekend to do Rust stuff, I regularly feel much more like doing "fun stuff" (like writing code/docs myself) rather than reviewing. If I would have more time for Rust I could do both (coding and reviewing), but that's a challenge to do in just my spare time.
Some of these were significant changes in the core of Miri so I feel I'd have to review them anyway even if someone else r+'d... not entirely sure what to do about that.
I'm very happy I dont get auto-assigned to PRs.^^

I strongly favor people leaving reviews without a final r+

This has come up in my $DAYJOB recently; it’s been semi-contentious.

The discussion has centered around who is responsible for seeing that the drive-by reviews are implemented. Does the assigned person have to check that every arbitrary comment was followed, even if they didn’t leave it?

There’s also the problem around what to do if multiple reviewers disagree on a point.

Another problem that I have experienced is around the strength of a suggestion. When reviewing, I might have a passing comment that means “oh it might be better to do this” and another comment that means “this must be done before this can be merged” but I am not always clear on directly stating that on every given point.

Another thing to keep in mind is that a contributor could feel overwhelmed if a large number of people were to review a pull request and comment on all the different things they see. It might feel like trying to defend your dissertation (I think; I have not experienced a dissertation myself :joy:)￼￼

Jake Goulding said:

Another thing to keep in mind is that a contributor could feel overwhelmed if a large number of people were to review a pull request and comment on all the different things they see.

even more so if the reviewers start arguing because they disagree on something.^^
OTOH, such discussions can be important and the PR is clearly the right place for them IMO.

And then add on to all of this the complexity that not every given human responds exactly the same way to each situation, so everything we say may or may not apply to any given person. Human interaction can be exhausting :sunglasses:
man, people. technology would be so much easier without them. :P
@XAMPPRocky That sounds like a great idea. Perhaps something to report as a wishlist issue on highfive?
Well I think it’d be triagebot at this point.
But yes, I can do that
Oh? What is the difference between the two?
highfive is the older tooling which is largely unmaintained, but triagebot is the replacement (and expansion in capability)

RalfJ said:

man, people. technology would be so much easier without them. :P

Yeah, especially users! They're always demanding little nit-picky things like readable fonts and correctness :(
Took me a bit but I've filed triagebot#558 around auto-assignment.

Just came across this thread. It's why we (triage-wg) have gone lax with the pinging strategy and we allow prs to stay unreviewed for a longer period so that reviewers get more time to work on the PRs. I'll go through this discussion again to see ways we can improve it :slight_smile:

Jake Goulding said:

This has come up in my $DAYJOB recently; it’s been semi-contentious.

Interesting points. I think maybe it would make sense to create some "guidelines" for writing "auxiliary reviews". I still think it's a net-win, but I would probably favor some rules like

  • mark clearly things that are suggestions, maybe we can adopt some standard terminology on this
  • avoid "wall of nit" reviews -- particularly if the PR author has asked for feedback on whether the approach is the right one. I'd probably try to limit the nits to things where we have relatively hard and fast rules (e.g., error messages with lowercase letter).

I think one thing that is really great (and rarely contentious) is to focus on the tests -- i.e., looking and thinking about things that should be tested is a really useful kind of review.

Anyway, I still think that "drive-by reviews" are good, and I suspect most PR authors are happy to get some prompt interaction versus silence (but there is a time when there's too much)

I think one thing that is really great (and rarely contentious) is to focus on the tests -- i.e., looking and thinking about things that should be tested is a really useful kind of review.

I agree! I find ideas for tests really useful when somebody's reviewing a PR of mine. It helps me understand the entire thing (the problem, the solution, and everything in between) a little bit better.

XAMPPRocky said:

Took me a bit but I've filed triagebot#558 around auto-assignment.

It would be great if we could not implement auto-assignment in triagebot, but also make some improvements to the auto-assignment system.

did you mean "if we could not only implement auto-assignment"?
the current text there confuses me.
Yes, that’s what I meant, sorry

Anecdote: I've noticed that I've been re-assigned PRs that have been sitting without reviews for days, and that I've had to re-assign my own PRs which have been sitting without reviews for days much more frequently in recent weeks than I've ever had to before.
(I don't mind doing the reviews, it's just in case there is something we could do)

Thought I'd just chime in with (possibly obvious) point that reviews are about a lot more than just the code to a lot of people. If people aren't active in Zulip, reviews are their number one point of contact with the community so reviews are really important for inclusion. Equally, I'm 100x more likely to want to keep contributing to something if I feel that I'm learning and I've learnt more from reviews and follow-up interactions with reviewers than anything else when it comes to Rust. I think a well-reviewed PR that turns out to be redundant/gets rejected is more valuable for the community and the contributor than just a rubber stamp.

@davidtwco chiming in from wg-triage, yeah we are being lenient on the triage at the moment, because it's trickier to re-assign reviews to a new reviewer if the new reviewer already has a list of reviews to be reviewed and we don't want to overload them. We have pushed the triage window from 8 days to 15 days. If you find any PR that's sitting idle for a long time, feel free to bring to my notice or post it in #t-release/triage so I can find out how we can tune our process in a better fashion. Thanks for the feedback :slight_smile:

Some thoughts from the contributor survey are also relevant here: if new contributors make a PR that ends up bitrotting or gets a very terse review, they are likely to be discouraged and stop contributing. So it might be worth it to make the review window very short for PRs made by new contributors, if that's feasible...
I think @Vadim Petrochenkov's original point that we need to be prioritizing doing reviews more than our own work was right on. It can be hard.
One other thing I would add:
I think we need a better mechanism for people to take breaks or go on vacation :)
e.g., I'm contemplating a vacation this summer, and I'd like to be able to take myself temporarily out of "auto-assignment" and so forth
we've said before that we need a way for folks to register that...

nikomatsakis said:

e.g., I'm contemplating a vacation this summer, and I'd like to be able to take myself temporarily out of "auto-assignment" and so forth

unacceptable... simply unacceptable (EDIT: I ruined my own joke)

Side note that I've adopted in the last few weeks a dedicated structure that is like 9am-noon is just reviews + notifications, every day. That has really helped me to get on top of things. I know this is a "full-time employee" sort of problem, I suppose.
But it is a real investment of time :)
...and I think I'm not even on the auto-assignment for t-compiler anymore?
I forget

I'm fortunate to have sufficiently few notifications - and normally only one or two PRs to review - at any given time that when I sit down to contribute, I can always look at those first, it definitely helps.

Regarding this point... I'm wondering if this might be a good way of ramping up new (serious) contributors? Perhaps assign them as a reviewer "apprentice" under some actual reviewer and have them discuss the PR?
One thing I will say is that I really like "pre-reviews", though there are complications
I will also say, though I'm not sure how helpful it is, that groups like we've formed around chalk, nll, and #t-compiler/wg-rfc-2229 help here a lot

nikomatsakis said:

e.g., I'm contemplating a vacation this summer, and I'd like to be able to take myself temporarily out of "auto-assignment" and so forth

Yes please! And that shouldn't be a global setting across all Rust teams; for instance, I'd like to be out of rotation for PR review assignment, but still review FCPs for the Rust language and Cargo teams.

nikomatsakis said:

Side note that I've adopted in the last few weeks a dedicated structure that is like 9am-noon is just reviews + notifications, every day. That has really helped me to get on top of things. I know this is a "full-time employee" sort of problem, I suppose.

for me, 9am-noon (less, really), is my entire dedicated Rust time for a day. as someone having a dayjob next to Rust, most of the time I have to push reviews to the weekend just because the during-the-week-Rust-time is filled with more urgent (think: keep Miri building) and/or more fun stuff. And then sometimes I dont get through my review queue in a weekend, so this quickly leads to multi-week waiting times.
Do we know what makes reviews less fun than other things? Any ideas for what we could do to make them more fun?
triage people pinging them every week
The Linux kernel sometimes gets stats published (by LWN) on who has done the most patch reviews (Reviewed-by) or sign-offs. That would be motivating.
For that matter, could we arrange to insert a Reviewed-by tag in the patch commit messages, for the reviewers?

The merge commit already contains r=reviewer_name. Eg Auto merge of #70946 - jumbatm:clashing-extern-decl, r=nagisa (
228a0ed)

Nadrieril said:

Do we know what makes reviews less fun than other things? Any ideas for what we could do to make them more fun?

I mean for me it's just my personal preference... I often find writing new code, exploring, puzzling, all that good stuff just much more fun than reading code someone else wrote and weighing whether something I see is important enough to be raised or more like a nit. Obviously the code won't look the way I would have written it so I have to find a balance where if it's too different then often I think it should be improved but also everyone has a different style.

Basically, reviewing involves interaction with another person and taking all that into account (not abusing my reviewer power, making them feel welcome, all these social concerns) is just much, much harder for me than coding.^^ Computers are so much easier to understand than people. ;) It also doesn't help that I am interacting with a stranger through a textbox. (Mentoring people in RL is a totally different game for me.)
This is very subjective, obviously. Not sure how much any of that generalizes.

Nadrieril said:

Do we know what makes reviews less fun than other things? Any ideas for what we could do to make them more fun?

I like doing reviews. But as Ralf noted, when you don't know the PR author well, you need to put in effort beyond the technical review. Some people may get demotivated by a super nitpicky review, others really dig that. But that actually doesn't influence my review speed. It's when I need to understand a part of the compiler that I'm not fluent in that causes me to sometimes leave the PR lying for a week before giving myself the push to actually review it.
I've also found that not knowing the author/reviewer and having to interact through GitHub makes it more draining, because I have to be extra careful about how I phrase things

I would love if more pr discussions happened here on zulip -
Some of the advantages:

  • it would encourage more discussion between the authors and reviewers
  • easier to follow for updates and triage work
  • less miscommunication and "deadlocks" of reviewers and authors waiting for each other
  • easier for another member to pick up the pr either as an author or reviewer

Sadly it will also mean people spending more time on reviews which may stretch out already stressed bandwidths but worth considering in the future

Being able to have bi-directional discussion about a PR would definitely help :slight_smile: it is quite likely that the person who implemented the change and interacted with the relevant portions of the compiler will be well poised to also explain the many whys and hows to the reviewer, if they did not understand something.
I really dislike it when a discussion is split into multiple parts in different chats/forums/etc.
this would also serve to enable contributors to expand their horizons.
It's much more convenient to have everything in a single github PR or issue.
Yeah, that's the downside.
This is why MCP as it's done now regresses things, IMO.
If there's enough cross linking, I think that's ok

But as a counter-point Rust is pretty much the only large project where I actually review complex changes without communicating with the author off-band in some way. Mostly for directed questions of "is there a reason you did this..." or "why was this done". It can be done on github too, but its a) higher latency; b) adds noise to the actual blocking comments.

Perhaps that's my dislikes to chats in general is leaking.
I only check discord and zulip twice a day (at least on work days), exactly in the same way as github, so there's no difference in latency.
I don’t think that enabling such a communication would serve to help review latency too much, however, now that I think about it.
In contrary to my original claim.
I conflated speed/throughput of the review with latency a bit too much in my head when writing that message.

I have only done a few non trivial reviews in recent months, but I did have some zulip discussions about pending PRs with the author and found that very useful. It didn't replace code review comments (blocking and non blocking), but it worked great as a complementary way to e.g. (1) work out CI failures (2) brainstorm better ways to do something (3) ping about current status. These are matters where the messages don't need to be attached to specific lines of code and are very ephemeral.
Of course, it's not gonna help if either reviewer or author strongly prefers PR comments over chat as a medium, which is valid.
Maybe we could make highfive post a zulip link that will create a new topic if used to write a message? Along with a message along the lines of "if you prefer a chat based discussion..."

@oli I think it would be nice to be able to create a zulip thread from any issue/PR on GitHub on rust-lang in general. Something like @rustbot create-topic t-compiler which would then create a new topic which links to GitHub and then posts a link to the topic on GitHub.
There's no need to create a topic. You can just create a url to a non-existing topic. E.g. https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/Foo.20bar.20.2370551

Huh, that's interesting. Though I think it might be confusing to click on something and see an empty screen, to me when I clicked on that it felt like I clicked on the wrong thing rather a new thing if that makes sense.
Maybe that's on Zulip though to have a more clear in the UI in that case.

The higher latency of GitHub chats is not just technical, it's UI. Even if messages were instant, something about the GitHub UI makes it feel less personal, and I won't engage with others in the same way I would on Zulip
That depends on the person of course. I happen to be comfortable with IRC-like chats

I really dislike it when a discussion is split into multiple parts in different chats/forums/etc.

True, but in most cases if there is a discussion especially something that's not directly related to the code in review but other aspects, people are reluctant to post it on the PR or if they do it ends up being buried it other conversations

if there is a discussion especially something that's not directly related to the code in review but other aspects, people are reluctant to post it on the PR

I second this, I had questions about https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/73532 that ended up with me spending an hour in discord with eddyb and opening an entirely different PR, I never would have been patient enough to do all that via github haha
